Technical Assistance Report 
 
Project Number: 49054-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
December 2019 
 
 
 
 
 
Digital Solutions to Improve Agricultural Value Chains 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB’s Access to Information 
Policy.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  AVC  –  agricultural value chain 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  Bambang Susantono, Knowledge Management and Sustainable 
Development 
Director General  WooChong Um, Sustainable Development and Climate Change 
Department (SDCC) 
Cluster Head  Chiara Bronchi, Chief Thematic Officer, SDCC 
Chief  Akmal Siddiq, Chief of Rural Development and Food Security 
(Agriculture) Thematic Group, SDCC 
   
Team leader  Samjhana Shrestha, Senior Economist, SDCC 
Team members  Maria Angela Banaria, Senior Operations Assistant, SDCC 
  Erin Lumanta-Sea, Associate Operations Analyst, SDCC 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
In preparing any country program or strategy, financing any project, or by making any designation 
of  or  reference  to  a  particular  territory  or  geographic  area  in  this  document,  the  Asian 
Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) aims to widen the use of digital 
technologies  in  Bangladesh,  Pakistan,  Tajikistan,  and  Viet  Nam  and  thereby  increase  the 
productivity and efficiency of production and marketing systems along agricultural value chains 
(AVCs). Administered by the Asian Development Bank (ADB), the TA will result in a commercially 
viable business model that encourages the broad participation of the public and private sectors 
as well as civil society, and boosts access to location-specific, reliable, and real-time information 
on (i) weather forecasts and alerts, (ii) irrigation scheduling, (iii) market information and analytics, 
and (iv) agricultural extension services. Helpline call centers set up in each country will provide 
information on best practices to improve crop production. 
 
2.  The TA supports a key priority of ADB’s Strategy 2030—to strengthen the use of high-
level technology in developing member countries (DMCs).1 It is included in the Management-
approved results-based work plan 2019 of the Sustainable Development and Climate Change 
Department.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Of about 422 million farms in Asia and the Pacific,3 about 380 million are smallholder farms 
that provide 80% of food in the region. Most smallholder farmers are tilling fragmented parcels of 
land totaling less than 1 hectare and cannot derive a livable income from farming. They face 
production, weather, disease, financial, and marketing risks. Market failure is one of the costliest 
risks. Providing technical and financial services to widely dispersed smallholders is costly and 
inefficient. 
 
4.  In addition, agriculture is increasingly exposed to climate change and globalization. Also, 
given that smallholder farming is back-breaking drudgery that does not generate fair returns on 
investments, youth are becoming disinterested in farming and migrate, and the average age of 
farmers has risen to 60. Women increasingly take their place, but the problems that smallholders 
face are compounded for women farmers, who have even less access to technical and financial 
services. However, modern and digital technologies—smartphones, internet of things, satellites, 
and drones—offer opportunities to provide such services to AVC stakeholders more efficiently 
and at much lower cost. 
 
5.  A major reason for inefficiencies in agriculture is inadequate access to reliable information 
on markets and weather. Up-to-date weather forecasts and real-time data on commodity and 
input prices will help farmers make informed decisions on the choice of crops, livestock, and 
fisheries; and adopt modern production and marketing practices. Information on weather patterns 
and  soil  moisture  content  will  help  farmers  improve  their  irrigation  practices.  Other  AVC 
stakeholders have similar difficulties in conducting their businesses efficiently because of limited 
access  to  reliable  and  timely  market  information.  Such  inefficiencies  result  in  lower  farm 
productivity and farmer incomes and higher prices for consumers. Access to nutritious food is 
constrained by high and highly variable prices, leading to malnutrition. 
 
 
1  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 17 May 2019. 
3  S.K. Lowder, J. Skoet, and T. Raney (Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations). 2016. The Number, 
Size, and Distribution of Farms, Small Farms, and Family Farms Worldwide. World Development. (87). pp. 16–29.

2 
6.  Digital innovations and technology may be part of the solution. The spread of mobile 
technology, remote-sensing services, and distributed computing are improving smallholders’ 
access to information, inputs, markets, finance, and training. Digital technology has created 
opportunities to integrate smallholders in a digitally driven agri-food system. It is providing real-
time access to reliable information, overcoming remoteness and exclusion cost-effectively. Digital 
technology,  such  as  smartphones,  satellite  imagery,  geographic  information  systems,  and 
artificial intelligence, may help identify pests and diseases, support irrigation scheduling and 
planning, and assist weather forecasts and alerts. Social media may help gauge public perception 
on outreach programs and crowdsource market-related information. 
 
7.  The TA will support four DMCs—Bangladesh, Pakistan, Tajikistan, and Viet Nam—that 
reflect the vital role of such technology in agriculture in their national policies and strategies. Vision 
2021 Digital Bangladesh prioritizes improving service delivery to increase efficiency and equity in 
agriculture.4 Bangladesh’s mobile industry has scaled up rapidly over the past decade to become 
the fifth-largest mobile market in Asia; half its population (85 million) became subscribers in 2017.5 
Digital Pakistan Policy envisions eAgriculture to support affordable and quality agricultural related 
services to AVCs.6 Tajikistan’s digital technology aspirations are articulated in the government’s 
decision to develop and implement information and communication technology.7 Viet Nam is keen 
to accelerate the use of digital technology in agriculture to improve productivity, quality, and 
competitiveness. 
 
8.  The selected DMCs offer significant potential to improve the efficiency along AVCs with 
digital technology. Smartphones is an effective tool for AVC stakeholders to access the internet. 
Falling smartphone prices and pay-as-you-go plans have contributed to greater affordability and 
accessibility of mobile devices, including in rural areas. Smartphone ownership and the use of 
mobile broadband have grown faster in developing countries in the last decade.  In 2018, 
subscription to mobile broadband plans exceeded 66% and smartphone adoption was 54% in 
Asia and the Pacific. Wider mobile phone penetration and the higher number of internet users 
have opened many opportunities for continued growth in sector development.8 
 
9.  Several examples in the selected DMCs show how digital technology improved AVCs. 
Telenor Velocity in Pakistan established an agri-tech start-up with three platforms: (i) Good Earth 
for farm machinery and tractor sharing, (ii) Pak Agri Market for a digital agriculture directory, and 
(iii) Pak Zar Zameen for multispectral imagery from satellites. Neksigol Mushovir, meanwhile, is 
a popular digital platform in Tajikistan that provides information on agriculture systems, such as 
crop production, livestock improvement programs, and agriculture trading. The key limitations of 
such endeavors are that they were developed in a sporadic manner with limited scale, are not 
linked to institutional systems, and do not constitute viable methods to ‘scale up’ and ‘scale out’ 
 
4  Government of Bangladesh, Ministry of Science and Information and Communication Technology. 2010. Digital 
Bangladesh  Strategy  in  Action.  Paper  presented  at the  Bangladesh  Development  Forum 2010.  Dhaka. 5–
16 February. 
5  M. Rogers. 2018. Country Overview Bangladesh—Mobile Industry Driving Growth and Enabling Digital Inclusion. 
London: GSM Association. 
6  Government of Pakistan, Ministry of Information Technology and Telecom. 2019. Digital Pakistan Policy. Islamabad. 
7  Government of Tajikistan. 2004. Development and Implementation of Information and Communication Technologies 
in the Republic of Tajikistan. Decision of the Government of the Republic of Tajikistan No. 468. Dushanbe. 
8  N.M. Trendov, S. Varas, and M. Zeng. 2019. Digital Technologies in Agriculture and Rural Areas: Briefing Paper. 
Rome: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations.

3 
the services.9  The TA aims to bridge these gaps by developing an inclusive business model that 
links public and private sectors and civil society in sharing and generating information and 
improving accessibility. The business model will include approaches for national replication and 
an exit strategy to auction off private sector to provide the services upon completion of the TA. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: agricultural productivity, food security, and 
incomes of AVC actors improved (footnote 1). The TA will have the following outcome: adoption 
of digital solutions along AVCs increased.10 Specifically, the TA will (i) improve the efficiency of 
and access to service delivery, (ii) introduce innovative methods and techniques, and (iii) enhance 
the possibility of scaling up high-level technology. 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
11.  The TA will be implemented in two phases. Under phase 1, the TA team will review 
business models that use digital technology to improve efficiencies in AVCs. The assessment will 
include  data  requirements  and  availability,  cost-effective  means  of  service  provision,  and 
availability of digital infrastructure and services. Following the assessment, the team will develop 
a commercially viable business model that encourages the participation of the public and private 
sectors as well as civil society. In doing so, it will pay close attention to achieving a business 
model that will bridge the gender digital gap. The business model will include action plans to link 
government institutions for better access to weather and market information, extension services, 
and technical advice to AVC stakeholders. The private sector and civil society will acquire any 
additional data that may be required for real-time and area-specific advice using various types of 
digital technologies. 
  
12.  Phase 2 will begin once the business model is established. It involves (i) developing, 
testing, and rolling out smartphone applications and messaging services; (ii) integrating weather, 
irrigation, market data, and extension services; (iii) compiling frequently asked questions and 
setting up networks of professionals to provide answers and technical advice; (iv) negotiating with 
telecommunication  companies  to  broadcast  mobile  applications  and  messaging;  and 
(v) launching protocols to engage the public and private sectors, including civil society. 
 
13.  Output 1: Business model to mainstream digital solutions for agricultural value 
chains developed. The TA team will develop a commercially viable business model to improve 
AVC efficiencies in each country. The business model will specify management processes for 
sharing public sector data and information, such as weather, farm management, and market data 
with private sector and other stakeholders. The private sector will play key roles in data analysis 
and  the  collection  of  additional  information  to  enable  timely  and  efficient  access  to  such 
information.  Service  provision  will  include  innovative  technology  provided  by  participating 
research  agencies  and  academia.  Service  operations  may  initially  be  subsidized  and then 
gradually run on a cost-recovery basis, until they gain commercial viability. The business model 
will include pathways and action plans for key stakeholders to deliver outputs 2 and 3. It will also 
 
9  The terms ’scale up’ and ‘scale out’ are used in digital infrastructure (compute, storage, networking) in reference to 
their ability to scale, grow larger over time without a wholesale replacement. What does “scale out” vs. “scale up” 
mean? https://packetpushers.net/scale-up-vs-scale-out/  
10 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
include TA initiation processes, action plans, quality assurance of outputs 2 and 3, and handover 
of services for upscaling upon TA completion. 
 
14.  Output 2: Digital applications for agricultural value chains operationalized. The 
output will result in the development and operationalization of four digital service platforms that 
provide (i) weather forecasts and alerts, (ii) irrigation scheduling advice, (iii) market information 
and  analytics,  and  (iv)  online  agricultural  extension.  Timely  weather  alerts,  forecasts,  and 
irrigation scheduling aim to mitigate crop vulnerability and improve irrigation productivity. Market 
information and trend analytics will help achieve better prices at farm gate (i.e., in sales directly 
from the producer) and at local markets. The agricultural extension service will provide best 
practices, and information will be shared in mobile applications and messaging services. 
 
15.  Output 3: Digital call centers for agricultural value chains operationalized. The TA 
team will set up a call center in each country to provide information on best practices that improve 
agricultural production. Trained call center operators will respond to queries using a database of 
frequently asked questions and answers. If the call center operations are unable to provide 
sufficient information and response, they will forward the queries to registered experts for timely 
response. Interactive voice response; satellite imagery; and various social media,11 including 
YouTube videos, will be used to reach out and provide advice to farmers.  Digital chat rooms 
could also be developed in DMCs where information sharing between peers and technical experts 
through digital technology has become effective. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $1 million,12 of which (i) $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund and (ii) $500,000 will be 
financed on a grant basis by the High-Level Technology Fund,13 both to be administered by ADB. 
The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. The $1 million budget will not be adequate to 
carry out the TA activities in all four DMCs, additional funding will be requested once activities are 
ongoing in Pakistan and the requirement for additional resources are clear.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  The TA will be implemented from January 2020 to December 2022. ADB is the executing 
agency and will administer the TA through the Rural Development and Food Security (Agriculture) 
Thematic Group under the Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department. The 
thematic group will handle overall supervision of TA implementation, including the selection and 
supervision of consultants, and the identification of resource persons for the workshops. The 
Ministries of Agriculture in Bangladesh and in Tajikistan, the Ministry of National Food Security 
and Research in Pakistan, and the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development in Viet Nam will 
be the implementing agencies. The ministries will facilitate coordination with their line agencies 
and other government agencies, such as extension, information technology, marketing, and 
metrology departments, to access information needed for the TA activities. Any additional data 
that may be required for real-time and area-specific advice will be acquired by the private sector 
and civil society using various digital technologies. The business developed under the TA support 
will be auctioned off 6 months before TA completion so that the private sector can commercially 
 
11 ADB. 2018. Staff Instruction on Business Processes for Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance. Attachment 
1: Optional Provisions under Technical Assistance Operations. Manila.  
12 ADB. 2015. Technical Assistance for Building Sustainable Food and Nutrition Security in Asia and the Pacific (Phase 
1). Manila (TA 9057). The TA 9057 has earmarked $150,000 to support the activities of this TA. 
13 Financing partner: The Government of Japan.

5 
provide the services. If the business cannot be sold in its entirety, a contingency plan is to sell the 
individual components of the business separately. 
 
18.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table.

19.  Consulting services. The services required under this TA are innovative and involve 
high-level technology, and there are market uncertainties about service availability and reliable 
cost estimates for such services. Therefore, ADB will use an early market engagement approach 
to select consultants, which means that it will invite potential firms to a conference call to present 
their perspectives, methodologies, and associated costs for carrying out the requisite tasks. 
Based on this information, detailed proposals will be sought for competitive bidding using 90:10 
quality- and cost-based selection and/or fixed budget selection.14 ADB will engage the consultants 
following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated 
project administration instructions and/or staff instructions.15  
 
20.  The TA will be implemented initially in Pakistan, where ADB has conducted consultation 
missions to engage the country’s public and private sectors and civil society. ADB is thus better 
prepared to implement the TA in Pakistan than in the other three selected DMCs. Once good 
progress has been made in Pakistan, the activities will be suitably adapted and rolled out in the 
other selected DMCs.16 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent 
of $500,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge 
Partnership Fund, and (ii) ADB administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent 
of $500,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the High-Level Technology Fund for Digital 
Solutions to Improve Agricultural Value Chains, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
14 Output-based or lump-sum contracts will be considered for consulting services where appropriate, with the 
concurrence of the Procurement, Portfolio, and Financial Management Department. 
15  Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3). 
16 A detailed discussion of the nature of the TA support is in Digital Solutions to Improve Agricultural Value Chains: A 
Synopsis (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

Key Activities with Milestones 
1.  Business model to mainstream digital solutions for AVCs developed 
1.1 Review policies and legislation on the establishment of business enterprises for digital networks 
(Q1 2020) 
1.2 Analyze market potential and subscription data and generate cash flow projections and possible cost-
recovery scenarios in Bangladesh, Pakistan, Tajikistan, and Viet Nam (Q1 2020–Q4 2020) 
1.3 Clarify roles for public and private sectors and civil society in the business model (Q1 2020–Q4 2020) 
1.4 Draft structure and legal documents for the proposed business enterprise (Q2 2020–Q4 2020) 
1.5 Submit a business proposal to relevant authorities for approval (Q4 2020) 
1.6 Test business model implementation (Q4 2020) 
1.7 Handover; secure transfer of project assets, products, and/or licenses to implementing agencies; and 
continue the memorandum of understanding (Q4 2022)

Appendix 1  7 
2.  Digital applications for AVCs operationalized 
2.1 Identify beneficiaries and assess the current use of digital networks in target areas (Q2 2020) 
2.2 Determine the agriculture-related information needs of farmers and other actors along the value chain 
(Q2 2020) 
2.3 Develop user-friendly and gender-sensitive digital networks catering to stakeholders along the value 
chain (Q1 2020) 
2.4 Design and roll out four mobile applications and messaging formats (Q2 2020) 
2.5 Test four mobile applications and incorporate changes based on evaluation and feedback during testing 
(Q3 2020) 
2.6 Roll out the mobile applications in selected districts for target commodities (Q3 2020) 
2.7 Monitor and evaluate the four mobile applications within 6 months of launch to assess implementation 
progress and recommend improvements based on feedback (Q1 2021) 
2.8 Produce country reports on findings and feedback on implementation and dissemination of the mobile 
applications, as well as on recommendations on expansion and/or future initiatives (Q2 2021–Q4 2022) 
 
3.  Digital call centers for AVCs operationalized 
3.1 Collect and collate back-end data on cropping systems and/or calendars, farm practices, pests, and 
diseases (Q2 2020) 
3.2 Develop a road map for the call centers with cost estimates of their operations (Q2 2020) 
3.3 Design and test implementation of the helpline call center in conjunction with the mobile applications 
rollout (Q3 2020) 
3.4 Establish a network of technical specialists for responding to callers (Q2 2020–Q32020) 
3.5 Train agricultural experts to produce short YouTube videos (Q2 2020) 
3.6 Develop and implement an outreach program for the call centers (Q2 2020–Q3 2020) 
3.7 Establish and maintain a database of callers, types of queries, and feedback on the services 
(Q2 2020–Q4 2022) 
3.8 Evaluate call center usage and YouTube subscription levels and update the services for improvement 
(Q1 2022) 
3.9 Produce country reports on findings and feedback on operating call centers and YouTube as well as 
recommendations on expansion and/or future initiatives (Q2 2022)
